brief_summary.textblock:
To determine the significance of a simple bedside clinical test (chest wall tenderness) to
      exclude myocardial ischemia in different demographic groups.

clinical_study.brief_title: Usefulness of Chest Wall Tenderness as Bedside Test to Exclude Acute Coronary Syndrome in Different Demographic Groups

detailed_description.textblock:
When a patient is presenting with acute chest pain at the ER of the University Hospital of
      Zurich, the study physician in charge, who is acting simultaneously as one of four attending
      clinical physicians, is performing the physical examination according to routine clinical
      practice.  The physical examination includes the testing of chest wall tenderness: Palpation
      of chest wall tenderness in lying 30° elevation of chest position. Flat index with
      standardized pressure where spontaneous maximum pain is reported (reproducible vs. not
      reproducible pain vs. no pain). Negative control (right side of chest mid-clavicle
      intercostal 6/7), reproducible vs. not reproducible pain vs. no pain. The same physician,
      who is blinded for the final diagnosis at the time of the physical examination, is also
      recording the patient history including the study interview using the standardized study
      questionnaire.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion criteria: All patients over the age of 18 years presenting with the leading
        symptom of first time or recurrent acute chest pain in the emergency room of the
        Department of Internal Medicine, University Hospital of Zurich.

        Exclusion criteria:

          -  Missing informed consent.

          -  Cardiopulmonary unstable patients.

          -  No self  reported chest pain.

          -  Recent thoracic surgery within1 year, inflammatory joint disease, fibromyalgia,
             cardiogenic shock.

study_pop.textblock: Patiens seaking the Emergency room of the University Hospital Zurich because of chest pain

intervention.description: The physical examination includes the testing of chest wall tenderness: Palpation of chest wall tenderness in lying 30° elevation of chest position. Flat index with standardized pressure where spontaneous maximum pain is reported (reproducible vs. not reproducible pain vs. no pain). Negative control (right side of chest mid-clavicle intercostal 6/7), reproducible vs. not reproducible pain vs. no pain.

facility.name: University Hospital Zurich, Division of Internal Medicine

clinical_study.official_title: Usefulness of Chest Wall Tenderness as Bedside Test to Exclude Acute Coronary Syndrome in Different Demographic Groups

overall_official.affiliation: University Hospital Zurich, Division of Internal Medicine

primary_outcome.description: Chest wall tenderness in patients presenting with acute chest pain and acute coronary syndrome (ACS) (ST-elevation myocardial infarction, STEMI/Non-ST-elevation myocardial infarction, NSTEMI /unstable angina pectoris) vs. chest wall tenderness in patients presenting with chest pain and without ACS in different demographic groups (Age under  vs. over 50 years; male vs. female, with vs. without CVRF).
primary_outcome.time_frame: From first presententation to omission (6-12 hours)

required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

secondary_outcome.description: Localization/Radiation of pain/first time/recurrent/ Patient thinks heart is the cause/ different CVRF/Illicit drugs/Medication - in combination with "reproducible/not reproducible pain" associated with ACS

clinical_study.study_design: Observational Model: Cohort, Time Perspective: Prospective
